Revolting against totalitarianism requires exceptional action:

"What is a rebel? A man who says no, but whose refusal does not imply a renunciation. [...] A slave who has taken orders all his life suddenly decides that he cannot obey some new command." 

- Camus (The Rebel)

1093181711540776960.text:
And the more numerous we are, the less we care:

“When all are guilty, no one is; confessions of collective guilt are the best possible safeguard against the discovery of culprits, and the very magnitude of the crime the best excuse for doing nothing. ” 

- Arendt (On Violence)

1093181615277248513.text:
Unfortunately, a large majority of the population is adept for totalitarianism:

"The choice for mankind lies between freedom and happiness and for the great bulk of mankind, happiness is better." 

- Orwell (1984)

1093181514043609088.text:
“The party told you to reject the evidence of your eyes and ears. It was their final, most essential command.” 

- Orwell (1984)

1093181432980230153.text:
"And if all others accepted the lie which the Party imposed—if all records told the same tale—then the lie passed into history and became truth. 'Who controls the past' ran the Party slogan, 'controls the future: who controls the present controls the past.’"

- Orwell (1984)

1093181294819840000.text:
“From the totalitarian point of view history is something to be created rather than learned [… It demands] the continuous alteration of the past, and in the long run probably demands a disbelief in the very existence of objective truth.”

- Arendt (The Origins of Totalitarianism)

He marched in 1989 when the Securitate started shooting at protestors.
He marched in February 2017 alongside 600,000 fellow Romanians.
He marched yesterday in the snow and freezing conditions at 82 years old.
He will march again tomorrow
#Resist
(6/8)

955151903897411585.text: My grandfather lived through 20 years of constant surveillance. Lived in a complete panopticon from 1970 to 1989: friends, neighbours, colleagues and even students reporting every action to the state police. (5/8)

955151902064431104.text:
Almost a year later, 100,000s of unrelenting citizens are still conquering the streets in abysmal conditions. 
Tens of hours in the -10°C snowy conditions, fighting against a same corrupt government that was put down 30 years ago in 1989. (4/8)

955151900638359552.text:
In February 2017, 600,000 Romanians marched in protest of a corrupt government, that’s putting the justice system under governmental control and decriminalising corruption. 

300,000 people marched the streets of Bucharest. 
That’s 16% of the capital’s population! (3/8)

955151897568067584.text:
These pictures were take almost a year apart in the streets of Bucharest, Romania. 
A year later, we're still fighting for the same cause (2/8)pic.twitter.com/QF6cMABpVH

955151895655518209.text: In disbelief that in 2018 people around the world still have to march for equality, freedom and political justice: the US Women’s March, political protests in Poland, Iran, Venezuela, Romania… The list goes on! (1/8)
